title: New clashes in Iraq see at least 18 people killed and total death toll near 100
text:
Advertisement

New clashes in Iraq have resulted in 18 people being killed as the death toll rises to close to 100, as protestors continue to demonstrate over corruption and unemployment.

Anti-government protestors in Baghdad were out in force last night as the cabinet tried to appease public anger by offering a new reform plan.

Nearly 100 people have died since Tuesday and the protests have taken local authorities by surprise. But the streets remained calm this morning, as many protestors have previously gathered momentum in the evening.

Just two year after the defeat of Islamic State in the region, corruption is still rampant and jobs remain scarce.

Last night Prime Minister Adel Abdul Madhi revealed his 17-point plan, which had been the result of emergency cabinet meetings.

Iraqi demonstrators burn tyres during a demonstration against state corruption, failing public services, and unemployment, in the Iraqi capital Baghdad last night

Iraqi Army troops deploy at a site of protests in Baghdad this morning following unrest last night. The streets remained quiet today

An Iraqi demonstrator gestures amidst smoke from burning tyres and tear gas during a demonstration against state corruption, failing public services and unemployment

It comes after vague offers of reform promises from the government which included subsidised housing for the poor, stipends for the unemployed as well as training programs and small loans initiatives for unemployed youth.

Families of those killed during the demonstrations are also set to receive pay-outs this week – something which is usually done for members of the security forces killed during war.

According to state TV the Prime Minister said: 'Amid all of this, I swear to God that my only concern is for the casualties.'

The streets of the capital were quiet on Sunday, however protesters have been gathering momentum later on in the day.

An Iraqi protester waves the national flag last night after a curfew was lifted and hundreds of security personnel were deployed

People were seen burning tyres last night. The largely spontaneous gathering of demonstrators in the city continued as their demands also continued to evolve

Iraqi demonstrators evacuate an injured man during a demonstration yesterday after many took to the streets

Clashes shattered calm on Saturday after a curfew was lifted in the centre of Baghdad and hundreds of security personnel were deployed.

The demonstrations started on Tuesday and have since spread to other cities in the south.

At least 18 people were killed in Nasiriya during the week after police fired live rounds at protesters. This is while twenty four people were also wounded in the clashes overnight, including seven policemen.

Protesters are also believed to have torched the headquarters of several political parties in the area.

Police said that violence had also broken out in Diwaniya, killing at least one person.
